Biology_222_r.News Finding: Co-author Dr Palmer said: "Our research has shown that non-native plants are less widespread than native species, and are not increasing any more than native plants.
Biology_222_r.Paper Finding: In addition, native plants may have the capacity to out-compete or coexist with the invaders, at least in some local environments .
Biology_222_r.News Context: Co-author Dr Palmer said: "Our research has shown that non-native plants are less widespread than native species, and are not increasing any more than native plants. It therefore seems likely that factors other than plant invasions are the main causes of vegetation change." The study found that locations with high diversity of non-native species also support high diversity of native species, suggesting that high diversities of native and non-native plant species are compatible with one another.
Biology_222_r.Paper Context: Competition may be insufficient as a mechanism to drive many or any native plant species extinct, other than at a local scale . In addition, native plants may have the capacity to out-compete or coexist with the invaders, at least in some local environments . However, it is possible to evaluate two conditions that need to be met if past introductions are likely to cause future extinctions.
Biology_222_r.text: ['Finding: Co-author Dr Palmer said: "Our research has shown that non-native plants are less widespread than native species, and are not increasing any more than native plants.']
Biology_222_r.displayed_text: Finding: Co-author Dr Palmer said: "Our research has shown that non-native plants are less widespread than native species, and are not increasing any more than native plants.

Biology_tweet_15_r.News Finding: In our latest article, just out in @username  we found that <0.1% of fungi, mostly belonging to Ascomycota, dominate soils globally. We mapped their global distribution and found that contain multiple genes related to stress-tolerance & resource uptake
Biology_tweet_15_r.Paper Finding: Whole-genome comparisons with less dominant, generalist fungi point at a significantly higher number of genes related to stress-tolerance and resource uptake in the dominant fungi, suggesting that they might be better in colonising a wide range of environments.
Biology_tweet_15_r.News Context: In our latest article, just out in @username  we found that <0.1% of fungi, mostly belonging to Ascomycota, dominate soils globally. We mapped their global distribution and found that contain multiple genes related to stress-tolerance & resource uptake
Biology_tweet_15_r.Paper Context: Our findings indicate that 83 phylotypes (<0.1% of the retrieved fungi), mostly belonging to wind dispersed, generalist Ascomycota, dominate soils globally. Whole-genome comparisons with less dominant, generalist fungi point at a significantly higher number of genes related to stress-tolerance and resource uptake in the dominant fungi, suggesting that they might be better in colonising a wide range of environments. Our findings constitute a major advance in our understanding of the ecology of fungi, and have implications for the development of strategies to preserve them and the ecosystem functions they provide.

Biology_417_r.News Finding: The researchers determined that, while climate change likely has been and will be a factor in the decline of some local populations such as in the Rocky Mountain West -- where the effect of a warming climate seems to be more severe for amphibians -- it is not responsible for the current declines that are occurring.
Biology_417_r.Paper Finding: While we demonstrate that amphibian communities are sensitive to changes in climate, our results suggest that changing climate is not the proximate cause for ongoing assemblage-wide declines that have been observed in North American amphibians.
Biology_417_r.News Context: For example, they found that less precipitation during breeding seasons generally has a negative effect on amphibian populations, while less snowfall during winter may benefit many populations. The researchers determined that, while climate change likely has been and will be a factor in the decline of some local populations such as in the Rocky Mountain West -- where the effect of a warming climate seems to be more severe for amphibians -- it is not responsible for the current declines that are occurring. "It depends on the location whether habitat loss, disease, contaminants, climate, or a combination of these local factors is the culprit," she said.
Biology_417_r.Paper Context: For example, we found that summer drought has the strongest impact in warm and dry regions, decreased snowfall has a smaller effect in eastern compared to western North America, and winter warming is predicted to decrease species richness for all species groups except tree frogs. While we demonstrate that amphibian communities are sensitive to changes in climate, our results suggest that changing climate is not the proximate cause for ongoing assemblage-wide declines that have been observed in North American amphibians. Instead, we find that recent change in climate is a strong predictor of why local species richness is declining more quickly in some regions and that positive effects of climate may be buffering declines in other regions.
Biology_417_r.text: ['Finding: The researchers determined that, while climate change likely has been and will be a factor in the decline of some local populations such as in the Rocky Mountain West -- where the effect of a warming climate seems to be more severe for amphibians -- it is not responsible for the current declines that are occurring.']

Biology_tweet_77_r.News Finding: What's a college student to do? Instant noodle intake associated with cardiometabolic risk factors.
Biology_tweet_77_r.Paper Finding: The consumption of instant noodles $2 times/wk was associated with a higher prevalence of metabolic syndrome in women [OR: 1.68; 95% CI: 1.10, 2.55; P-trend < 0.01, P-interaction (gender 3 instant noodle intake) = 0.04] and marginally higher abdominal obesity in women (OR: 1.48; 95% CI: 0.99, 2.21; Ptrend = 0.06) but not in men ( Table 5 ).
Biology_tweet_77_r.News Context: What's a college student to do? Instant noodle intake associated with cardiometabolic risk factors.
Biology_tweet_77_r.Paper Context: The exclusion of participants taking blood pressurelowering or lipid-lowering medications or who had a history of diabetes mellitus did not change the overall associations between dietary patterns and cardiometabolic risk factors. The consumption of instant noodles $2 times/wk was associated with a higher prevalence of metabolic syndrome in women [OR: 1.68; 95% CI: 1.10, 2.55; P-trend < 0.01, P-interaction (gender 3 instant noodle intake) = 0.04] and marginally higher abdominal obesity in women (OR: 1.48; 95% CI: 0.99, 2.21; Ptrend = 0.06) but not in men ( Table 5 ). Consumption of instant noodles once per week was also associated with a higher prevalence of metabolic syndrome in women (OR: 1.26; 95% CI: 1.06, 1.50) but not in men.
Biology_tweet_77_r.text: ['Finding: What\'s a college student to do? Instant noodle intake associated with cardiometabolic risk factors. ']
Biology_tweet_77_r.displayed_text: Finding: What's a college student to do? Instant noodle intake associated with cardiometabolic risk factors.

Biology_71_r.News Finding: The BioBits kits enable us to expose young kids, older kids, and even adults to the wonders of synthetic biology and, as a result, are poised to transform science education and society.
Biology_71_r.Paper Finding: We anticipate that the availability of our BioBits™ kits and the data reported here will encourage teaching and broaden participation in the field of synthetic biology.
Biology_71_r.News Context: "We show that it is possible to use freeze-dried, cell-free extracts along with freeze-dried synthetic biology components to conduct innovative educational experiments in classrooms and other low-resource settings. The BioBits kits enable us to expose young kids, older kids, and even adults to the wonders of synthetic biology and, as a result, are poised to transform science education and society. This BioBits project demonstrates the kind of out-of-the-box thinking and refusal to accept the status quo that we value and cultivate at the Wyss Institute, and we all hope it will stimulate young people to be intrigued by science," said Wyss Institute Founding Director Donald Ingber, M.D., Ph.D., who is also the Judah Folkman Professor of Vascular Biology at Harvard Medical School (HMS) and the Vascular Biology Program at Boston Children's Hospital, as well as Professor of Bioengineering at Harvard's John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS).
Biology_71_r.Paper Context: Titrating the amount of DNA template results in varying levels of fluorescent protein production, which are visible to the naked eye and under a blue or black light. We anticipate that the availability of our BioBits™ kits and the data reported here will encourage teaching and broaden participation in the field of synthetic biology. We observed that all proteins expressed with high soluble yields (between 160 and >1100 g ml −1 ) ( Fig.

Biology_71_r.displayed_text: Finding: The BioBits kits enable us to expose young kids, older kids, and even adults to the wonders of synthetic biology and, as a result, are poised to transform science education and society.

Biology_422_r.News Finding: Then the team identified 27 unique bacterial features unique to the gut microbiomes, and thus stool, of people with NAFLD-cirrhosis.
Biology_422_r.Paper Finding: This study leverages from a unique and well-characterized cohort including participants with NAFLD-cirrhosis which allows studying the specific gutmicrobiome signature of this extreme and well-defined clinical phenotype.
Biology_422_r.News Context: In addition, they observed that people with extreme forms of NAFLD had less diverse and less stable gut microbiomes. Then the team identified 27 unique bacterial features unique to the gut microbiomes, and thus stool, of people with NAFLD-cirrhosis. The researchers were able to use this noninvasive stool test to pick out the people with known NAFLD-cirrhosis with 92 percent accuracy.
Biology_422_r.Paper Context: Hence, this conveniently assessed microbial biomarker could present an adjunct tool to current invasive approaches to determine stage of liver disease. This study leverages from a unique and well-characterized cohort including participants with NAFLD-cirrhosis which allows studying the specific gutmicrobiome signature of this extreme and well-defined clinical phenotype. The fundamental difference between the previous study and the present study is the clinical context of use of the gut-microbiome signature.
Biology_422_r.text: ['Finding: Then the team identified 27 unique bacterial features unique to the gut microbiomes, and thus stool, of people with NAFLD-cirrhosis.']
Biology_422_r.displayed_text: Finding: Then the team identified 27 unique bacterial features unique to the gut microbiomes, and thus stool, of people with NAFLD-cirrhosis.
